page.title: 20THE QUAY (POEM)
page.content: {Swans}preen themselves on the blue- brown waters,{With}arched necks they drink and fight.{Horses}on the reedy bank eat grass contentedly,{Their} manes entangle in the occasional breezes,{They}look up, slightly disturbed,as a noisy motor boat{With}a man steers it towards their domain.{ {Still}boats seem to be moving forward, {But}it's just the ripples on the river.{A distant}rattle of rigging hitting the masts,{Getting}louder and more frequent{As}a harsh breeze sweeps past.{The}warming sun makes the murky waters{Sparkle}and catch attention.{ {Children}run and play in and out of various swings and see-saws.{The}field is mown in neat stripes;{People}flock to it to soak up the sun.{The}peace is broken by dogs barking,{Chasing}each other,{But}then,summer reigns on.
